qas.question: How are performers expected to play a work due to written transmission?

answers.text: in a way that realizes in detail the original intentions of the composer

qas.question: When did details that composers put in their scores increase?
Admiration of performers for new interpretations can be seen when composers feel the performer achieve what?

answers.text: a better realization of the original intent than the composer

qas.question: What do classical performers often achieve?

context: Its written transmission, along with the veneration bestowed on certain classical works, has led to the expectation that performers will play a work <a0_0>in a way that realizes in detail the original intentions of the composer<a0_0/>. During <a1_0>the 19th century<a1_0/> the details that composers put in their scores generally increased. Yet the opposite trend—admiration of performers for new "interpretations" of the composer's work—can be seen, and it is not unknown for a composer to praise a performer for achieving <a2_0>a better realization of the original intent than the composer<a2_0/> was able to imagine. Thus, classical performers often achieve <a3_0>high reputations for their musicianship<a3_0/>, even if they do not compose themselves. Generally however, it is the composers who are remembered more than the performers.
